intro: Parasitipomoea, commonly known as the parasitic morning glory, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Convolvulaceae. These plants are hemiparasitic, meaning they derive some nutrients from their host plants while also performing photosynthesis. They typically have showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are often blue or purple in color. The leaves are usually alternate and can be heart-shaped or ovate. Parasitipomoea species are found in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing in association with other plants in forested areas.
